Tolosa 72 San Sebastián 20018 Spain Graphical abstract Single-atom catalysts (SACs) display prominent performance and high metal utilization for numerous catalytic processes. Harnessing the interaction between single atoms and supports is crucial to improve the performance of SACs. By means of density functional theory calculations and microkinetic modeling including adsorbate interactions, we expose the promising synergy between 3d–5d single metal atoms (M) and TiO2(110) for CO oxidation. Upon a rigorous analysis, we identify the adsorption energy of O at M sites as a simple and robust descriptor to abridge the design of catalysts for CO oxidation on M/TiO2 catalysts, so that enhanced activities are predicted at mild O adsorption energies. Single Pt and Rh atoms provide the largest enhancement around 400 K, with CO2 formation rates 7–8 orders of magnitude higher than on TiO2(110). Non-precious Ta/TiO2 and Mn/TiO2 also exhibit salient activities. This work highlights the often disregarded yet central role of adsorbate interactions in CO oxidation. Keywords Single-atom catalyst Rutile oxide CO oxidation DFT calculations Microkinetic modeling Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Supported single-atom catalysts (SACs) have attracted considerable interest in recent years in view of their enhanced catalytic performance and higher metal utilization in comparison to supported metal catalysts. Great promise is held for important catalytic processes including oxidation [1–3] and hydrogenation reactions [4], oxygen reduction [5–7], CO2 reduction [8], photocatalytic water splitting [9], and numerous other reactions [10,11]. Importantly, incorporating a metal atom on an ionic support such as a metal oxide often implies that the SACs become cationic and, thus, their properties differ visibly from those of supported metal catalysts. In fact, the valence states of metal atoms can have a significant influence on the adsorption energies of reaction intermediates [12] and the overall catalytic performance [13], opening new possibilities to substitute precious metal catalysts by cheap and abundant metal cations by engineering catalyst-support interactions. In supported SACs, the electronic structure of the support can vary dramatically upon the incorporation of the individual atoms. For instance, the presence of SACs facilitates the formation of oxygen or sulfur vacancies on oxide or sulfide supports [14,15]. A synergetic interaction between SACs and such vacancies exists that helps catalyze a variety of reactions [16–18]. Specifically, CO molecules adsorb on single Rh or Pd atoms and an adjacent oxygen vacancy activates H2O molecules, providing enhanced activity and selectivity for the water–gas shift (WGS) on TiO2 and FeO x surfaces [16,17]. Moreover, a suitable combination of metal atoms and supports makes Pt1/FeO x SACs 2−3 times more active than the subnanometer counterparts for CO oxidation and its preferential oxidation in H2 [1]. However, FeO x -supported single Ir atoms exhibit lower activity for the two reactions than Ir subnanometer clusters [19]. These examples illustrate the need for a fundamental understanding of the interactions between SACs and supports, such that clear guidelines are established to find suitable combinations for specific catalytic reactions. These insights would definitely accelerate the design and implementation of SACs in many branches of catalysis. DFT-calculated activation energies and adsorption energies can be inputted into suitable microkinetic models to assess the kinetics of catalytic reactions, thereby connecting the atomic-scale properties and the macroscopic functionality of the catalyst. Often, microkinetic models use the activation energies of elementary reactions calculated with respect to the separate adsorption of species [20,21], which is a fair simplification as long as the interactions between adsorbed species are small. However, supported SACs may display strong metal-support interactions that in turn influence their catalytic activities. In such case, sizable deviations in the activation energies and reaction mechanism from the separate adsorption (SA) picture can be expected. Therefore, it is crucial to appraise if substrate-modulated interactions between species are important in SACs. By means of DFT calculations and microkinetic simulations including the interactions between intermediates (co-adsorption model, CA) or discarding them (separate adsorption model, SA), here we study how the reaction mechanism and catalytic activity for CO oxidation change as a function of the SAC added to a TiO2 catalyst. CO oxidation is markedly important in car-exhaust emission control, CO2 lasers, air purification, etc. As it is one of the simplest catalytic reactions, it is extensively used as a probe to understand more complex catalytic processes [22–27]. In a previous study, single atoms of Ir embedded in rutile TiO2 were synthesized by tuning the Ir content at 0.1 wt%, using an incipient-wetness impregnation method [28]. Aberration-corrected high-angle annular darkfield (AC-HAADF) images and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) showed that all Ir species in 0.1 wt% Ir/TiO2 are single atoms, positively charged with a structure similar to that of the IrO2 phase but different from that of Ir foil. The 0.1 wt% Ir/TiO2 catalyst is stable under typical reverse water gas shift (rWGS) reaction conditions (623 K, CO2/H2 = 1). Indeed, similar crystal structure and lattice constants between MO2 and rutile TiO2 are known to stabilize single atoms (M) embedded in the titania lattice [28]. Thus, M is chosen here as a 3d-5d metal with rutile-type oxide structure, namely M = V, Cr, Mn, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Ta, W, Os, Ir and Pt. Furthermore, single-atom Rh/TiO2-P25 catalysts have been shown to be promising for the water gas shift reaction, which comprises CO oxidation [16]. As TiO2-P25 includes both rutile and anatase phases, we choose the typically more abundant rutile phase in our study despite the higher stability of the anatase phase in the temperature range studied (320–500 K). We show that adsorbate interactions are crucial to accurately calculating the kinetics of CO oxidation on M/TiO2(110). In particular, Pt/TiO2(110) and Rh/TiO2(110) exhibit the largest enhancement at temperatures below and above 400 K, and their formation rate of CO2 is 7–8 orders of magnitude higher than on TiO2(110). An intuitive descriptor-based analysis abridges the model and reveals that such noteworthy activities can be expected when O adsorption is moderate at the M site of M/TiO2(110). 2 Methods Spin-polarized DFT calculations of TiO2(110) and M/TiO2(110) (M = V, Cr, Mn, Nb, Mo, Ru, Rh, Ta, W, Os, Ir and Pt) were performed using VASP [29] with the PBE exchange–correlation functional [30]. Because no rutile-type oxide structure is available for Pd, we did not consider it in the present study. We randomly chose M = Mn, Rh and Ta from 3d to 5d metals and investigated the effect of spin on the total energies of reduced M/TiO2(110) (denoted as M/TiO2- x (110)). As shown in Fig. S1, unconstrained spin calculations (as opposed to fixing the total magnetic moment) find the total energies of these systems and are thus used in this work; the optimized magnetic moments of the stoichiometric and reduced M/TiO2(110) surfaces are listed in Table S1. The interaction between ionic cores and electrons was described by the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method [31,32]. The Kohn–Sham wavefunctions of valence electrons (3d4s for Ti-Mn; 4p5s4d for Nb; 5s4d for Mo, Ru, Rh; 6s5d for Ta, W, Os, Ir, Pt; 2s2p for C, O) were expanded in a plane-wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV. Zero-point energy (ZPE) corrections to the total DFT energies were included. The lattice constants of bulk TiO2 in the rutile crystalline system were calculated to be a = b = 4.67 Å, c = 2.97 Å, in fair agreement with the experimental values (a = b = 4.59 Å, c = 2.96 Å) [33]. As shown in Fig. 1 , TiO2(110) was modeled with a four O−Ti−O trilayer slab with (4 × 1) periodicity. M/TiO2(110) was modeled by substituting one of the eight surface Ti atoms by M on the (4 × 1) TiO2(110) slab. A vacuum region of at least 15 Å was used along the z-direction to avoid electrostatic interactions between repeated slabs. The two bottommost layers were fixed at the bulk distances, and the two topmost layers and the adsorbates were fully relaxed. The surface Brillouin zone was sampled with a (2 × 4 × 1) Monkhorst-Pack [34] k-point grid for TiO2(110) and M/TiO2(110). The energy (ΔE Sub) for substituting Ti by M on TiO2(110) is: (1) Δ E Sub = E M / T i O 2 + E Ti - E TiO 2 - E M where E TiO 2 , E M / T i O 2 , E Ti and E M represent the energies of TiO2(110), M/TiO2(110), a Ti atom and a dopant atom in vacuum, respectively. The formation energy of bridge oxygen vacancies (ΔE Vac) is: (2) Δ E Vac = E M / T i O 2 - x + 1 2 E O 2 - E M / T i O 2 where E M / T i O 2 and E M / T i O 2 - x are the energy of stoichiometric and reduced M/TiO2(110), and E O 2 is the gas-phase energy of O2. The adsorption energy (ΔE Ads) was calculated using the most stable adsorption configurations (E slab+ad) relative to the clean surfaces (E slab) and the isolated adsorbates (E ad): (3) Δ E Ads = E slab + a d - E slab - E ad To avoid the direct calculation of the total energy of O2, which is generally problematic within the DFT formalism [35], we calculated the total energy of O2 using the DFT-assessed free energies of H2 and H2O and the experimental free energy change (2.46 eV) of the reaction H 2 O l → H 2 ( g ) + 1 2 O 2 ( g ) [35–38]. In addition, the total energies of CO(g) and CO2(g) were corrected by −0.24 and 0.19 eV following a previous study to ensure that the DFT-calculated free energy of CO oxidation matches the experimental one (−2.67 eV) [39]. Bader charge analysis was performed using a grid-based weight method [40] in which the expression for the fraction of space neighboring each grid point flowing to its neighbors is used as a weight for the discrete integration of functions over the Bader volume. Positive or negative charges mean charge depletion or charge accumulation, respectively. The crystal orbital overlap populations (COOP) were computed and analyzed using the LOBSTER program [41]. COOP is an overlap-population-weighted density of states that provides information on electron distribution [42]. In turn, the integrated COOP is useful to describe adsorption-energy trends among different materials [43], or coordinatively different sites of the same material [44]. All transition states (TSs) were located by the climbing-image nudged elastic band method (CI-NEB) [45] and the force reversed method [46], and saddle points were confirmed when a single imaginary frequency was observed along the reaction coordinate. The relaxations stopped when the residual forces on each atom were below 0.03 eV/Å. The elementary activation barrier (ΔE Act) and reaction energy (ΔH) were calculated with respect to the most stable co-adsorption state of the species in the initial states unless otherwise stated. We previously investigated the effect of the Hubbard U parameter [47] on the adsorption energies of O, the activation energies and reaction energies of CO2 and N2O decomposition on MO2(110) (M = 3d metals from Ti to Ni) and found that it does not alter the trends [48]. Because we primarily concentrate on the trends in this work, U was not included. The reaction temperature in this study ranges from 320 to 500 K, and the total pressure is kept at 1 bar with a CO/O2 ratio of 2. More details about the microkinetic model can be found in section S18. The degree of rate control of step i ( D RC , i ) [49] helps quantitatively determine the significance of a given step i in the overall reaction and is defined as: (4) D RC , i = k i r ∂ r ∂ k i k j ≠ i , K i = ∂ ln r ∂ ln k i k j ≠ i , K i where ki, Ki and r are the forward rate constant, the equilibrium constant for elementary step i and the reaction rate, respectively. A positive value of D RC , i means that step i is a rate-limiting step, and decreasing its activation energy increases the overall rate. Negative values are associated with inhibition steps, for which lowering the barriers decreases the overall rate. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Modeling the M/TiO2(110) catalyst There are two types of surface Ti atoms that can be substituted by a single metal atom M on a stoichiometric TiO2(110) surface, marked as I and II in Fig. 1a. Fig. S2 and Table S2 show that the energy (ΔE Sub, see definition in the Methods section) for substituting TiI by M (Fig. 1b) is higher than for TiII (Fig. 1c) by 0.03–1.23 eV. However, the case is different in presence of 25 % bridge oxygen vacancies, where the former site (Fig. 1e) generally has lower ΔE Sub than the latter (Fig. 1f) by 0.13–0.43 eV (Fig. S2 and Table S2). These results indicate that substituting TiII by M is thermodynamically more stable under oxidative atmospheres, whereas substituting TiI is preferable under reductive atmospheres. We emphasize that ΔE Sub is assessed only to compare the relative stability of M at different locations. Note that metal salts are typically used to synthesize the SACs in experiments and the type of salt depends on M, and SACs are often metastable [13]. Hence, it is not our intention to address the synthesizability of SACs in this work. TiI is sterically more accessible for M substitution than TiII, which is blocked by bridge oxygen atoms. Therefore, M substitution of TiI on the stoichiometric and reduced TiO2(110) surface (Fig. 1b, e) is used here to model CO oxidation on M/TiO2(110) catalysts, and we assume that the location of M does not change during the reaction process. As discussed later in this work, the surface diffusion of SACs is difficult once they occupy a substitutional position in the lattice and, although their diffusion into the bulk might be thermodynamically favorable in some cases (Table S16), large kinetic impediments are expected at the temperatures considered here. Having ascertained the location of M, we investigated its effect on the formation of bridge oxygen vacancies on TiO2(110) (Fig. 1e). Compared to stoichiometric TiO2(110), ΔE Vac on the stoichiometric M/TiO2(110) decreases by 0.10–2.16 eV (Fig. S3 and Table S3), indicating that M facilitates the formation of adjacent oxygen vacancies. These results are consistent with those of a previous theoretical study [50]. Moreover, as the number of outer electrons [12] of M (NM) increases in Fig. S3, ΔE Vac on the stoichiometric M/TiO2(110) progressively decreases, implying an easier formation of oxygen vacancies for surfaces with late transition metal dopants. To understand the nature of the bond between bridge oxygen and Ti in M/TiO2, we provide differential charge density maps for M = Ta, W, Os, Pt in Fig. 2 . We observe considerable charge withdrawal from Ti by O in TiO2, Ta/TiO2 and W/TiO2, which is indicative of markedly ionic bonds. When M = Os, Pt, a sizeable charge depletion from both Ti and O centers and accumulation between them is seen, suggesting that the bonds are now covalent. Thus, bridge O–Ti bonds switch from ionic to covalent as M moves to the right of the periodic table, which in turn decreases ΔE Vac. Interestingly, the switch of bond type of bridge O–M has also been seen in rutile MO2(110) when M is a 3d metal [48]. The Bader charge of M is positive on both stoichiometric and reduced M/TiO2(110), as shown in Fig. S4 and Table S4. Compared with stoichiometric M/TiO2(110), the Bader charge of M on reduced M/TiO2(110) is smaller by 0.04–0.46 e−. This is reasonable because the removal of a bridge O atom leaves free electrons in the reduced M/TiO2(110) surface, resulting in less electron withdrawal from M. Moreover, as M moves to the right of the periodic table, the decrease in Bader charge of M on the reduced M/TiO2(110) becomes larger. For instance, the Bader charge of Ta on stoichiometric Ta/TiO2(110) is larger than on reduced Ta/TiO2(110) by only 0.04 e−. However, the difference in Bader charge of Pt between stoichiometric and reduced Pt/TiO2(110) is as large as 0.46 e−. These results agree with the differential charge density maps in Fig. 2 (lower panels): the formation of bridge O-Ti bonds causes large charge variations in Os/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2, in contrast with pure TiO2, Ta/TiO2 and W/TiO2, where there is no noticeable charge transfer on Ti, Ta and W. This is because bridge O interacts more strongly with the 5d states of Os and Pt near the Fermi level (see Fig. S5) compared to those of W and Ta and the 3d states of Ti. 3.2 Adsorption of intermediates and elementary steps Two primary mechanisms, i.e., dissociative and associative, have been proposed for CO oxidation. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the dissociative mechanism involves CO oxidation by adsorbed atomic O, obtained from the dissociation of O2* (Route I) or O2*(II) (Route II). Furthermore, CO can directly react with adsorbed molecular oxygen, leading to the formation of CO2. As shown in Fig. 3b–d, several associative routes (Routes III-VIII) are available, and they differ in the co-adsorption structure of CO and O2 and whether or not CO3 is formed. We note that CO3 is often regarded as a possible intermediate on Au-based catalysts [51–53]. It can be seen that lattice O (bridge O) participates in the CO oxidation reaction and is recovered by O from gaseous oxygen in all the dissociative and associative mechanisms considered. That is to say, we consider different Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanisms (I-VIII) [54], involving both reduced (M/TiO2-x, Fig. 3) and stoichiometric (O*, Fig. 3) M/TiO2(110). We first investigated the adsorption of various intermediates involved in the two aforementioned mechanisms on the reduced and stoichiometric M/TiO2(110), and the adsorption energies (ΔE Ads) and structures are shown in Table S5 and Fig. S6. We studied a number of configurations for O2 adsorption on reduced M/TiO2(110), and only the two most stable configurations on most surfaces are summarized for brevity, namely O2 at the bridge O vacancy (denoted as O2*) and O2 at both bridge O vacancy and M (denoted as O2*(II), Fig. S6a and b). Table S5 shows that O2*, O2*(II) and O* (Fig. S6c) bind significantly weaker by 1.80–2.26 eV with increasing number of outer electrons of M on reduced M/TiO2(110). This is related to the aforementioned switch in bridge O–Ti bond type on M/TiO2(110) depending on M. We found a substrate-mediated interaction between bridge O (O*) and co-adsorbed O (OM) or CO (COM) at M sites. The interaction energy (ΔE Int) is defined as the difference between ΔE Ads of OM or COM on stoichiometric and reduced M/TiO2. As shown in Fig. S7a and Table S6, ΔE Int between O* and OM is more positive when M is an early transition metal such as Ti, Ta, Nb, V, Cr, Mo and Mn, which is indicative of strong repulsive interactions. However, if M is a late transition metal such as Ru and Os, a strong repulsion is found between O* and COM (Fig. S7b). For Pt/TiO2, a rather negative ΔE Int is found for both O* and OM, and O* and COM, implying strong attraction between them. Further energetic and electronic-structure analyses about OM and COM adsorption with or without the presence of O* appear in sections S7 and S8. Those strong interactions lead to a large difference in the activation energies (ΔE + and ΔE − for forward and backward reactions) of relevant elementary reactions calculated by separate adsorption and co-adsorption, see Table S7. In fact, on Pt/TiO2, the strong attraction between O* and OM and COM results in rather negative ΔE + or ΔE − values for most elementary reactions in the separate adsorption (SA) model (Table S7). This indicates that the SA model fails to describe the energetics of elementary reactions with strong interactions between reactants or products, and in this case such interactions ought to be considered, as will be shown later. For this important reason, we use the energetics of the systems with co-adsorption (CA model) and treat the bridge O vacancy and M as a joint site * for convenience. We primarily present the results of the CA model below unless otherwise stated. According to the dissociative mechanism, adsorbed O2* (Route I, Fig. 3a) or O2*(II) (Route II, Fig. 3a) decompose into adsorbed O at the bridge oxygen vacancy and adsorbed O at the M site (denoted (2O)*). Route I is found on various M/TiO2 surfaces except M = Ti, Cr, Mn, Rh, Pt, and ΔE+ of O2* dissociation is in the range of 0.26–0.93 eV. The energetics and TS structures appear in Table S7 and Fig. 3e–o. Route II is observed on all M/TiO2 surfaces except for Mo/TiO2 and Os/TiO2, where no stable O2*(II) adsorption state was observed. ΔE+ of O2*(II) dissociation ranges from 0 to 1.26 eV. Both routes exist when M = V, Nb, Ru, Ta, W, Ir, as shown in Table S7, and O2*(II) dissociation has lower ΔE+ than O2* dissociation by 0.26–0.93 eV. The dissociated O atoms (2O)* combine with CO (CO#) at the Ti site leading to CO2 formation ((CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + #, see Fig. 3a), and ΔE+ is in the range of 0.21–1.30 eV on M/TiO2(110). Compared to (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + #, the range spanned by ΔE+ of the step (CO + O)* = CO2 + * is narrower (0.40–0.86 eV). This is reasonable as both O and CO binding (O* on M/TiO2-x and COM on M/TiO2) affect ΔE+ , and ΔE Ads of O* and COM show opposite trends with M (Table S5). The associative mechanism can proceed through (CO + O2)* = CO2 + O* (Route III, Fig. 3b) on most surfaces except where direct O2 dissociation is facile, as is the case of M = Nb, Mo, Ta, W. ΔE+ of (CO + O2)* = CO2 + O* is typically above 1 eV, suggesting that this route is unlikely to proceed. Alternatively, CO* can react with O2*, leading to the formation of *CO3, which then undergoes O–O bond scission to yield CO2 on Mn/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 (Route IV, Fig. 3b). Compared to Route III, the barriers for the elementary reactions in Route IV are lower and no larger than 0.70 eV (Table S7). In addition, the route of (CO + O2)*(II) = CO2 + O* (Route V, Fig. 3c) is also found on Cr/TiO2, has ΔE+ = 0.39 eV and is lower than that of Route III by 0.64 eV on this surface. Moreover, CO* can react with O2*(II) (Route VI, Fig. 3c) on M/TiO2 (M = Ti, V, Mo) or O2*(III) (Route VII, Fig. 3d) on M/TiO2 (M = Ru, Rh, Os, Ir) or O2*(IV) (Route VIII, Fig. 3d) on Ta/TiO2, yielding a *CO3 intermediate that decomposes into CO2 and O*. ΔE+ of the elementary reactions in these routes goes from 0.07 to 0.81 eV, which is lower than the corresponding values of Route III. There are approximate Brønsted-Evans-Polanyi (BEP) relations [55–57] between the activation energies (ΔE+ ) and reaction energies (ΔH) for O2*(II) decomposition, (CO + O)* = CO2 + *, (CO + O2)* = CO2 + O*, (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + # and CO3* = CO2 + O* on M/TiO2(110), as shown in Fig. S13 and Table S8. Considering that the reactions take place on multiple sites, such as bridge oxygen vacancy and M and Ti sites and involve clear bonding variations of the intermediates, the correlations provide predictions with reasonable mean absolute errors. 3.3 Microkinetic modeling Using the DFT calculated energetics, microkinetic simulations were conducted at typical CO oxidation conditions (320–500 K, 1 bar, PCO/PO2 = 2) [58–60]. Details of the microkinetic model are given in section S18. Fig. 4 a shows that the rate of CO2 formation increases with temperature on all M/TiO2(110) surfaces. Introducing Pt, Rh, Ta, Mn, Ir, Ru, Nb, V, Cr and Os atoms accelerates CO oxidation on TiO2(110). Pt atoms exhibit the largest enhancement below 400 K, with a CO2 formation rate 7–8 orders of magnitude higher than that of undoped TiO2(110). In turn, Rh/TiO2(110) is the most active system at higher temperatures and has a higher CO2 formation rate than TiO2(110) by 7 orders of magnitude. This agrees well with the experimental observation that single-atom Rh/TiO2 catalysts are promising for the WGS [16], as CO oxidation is a key part of that process. Nonprecious Ta/TiO2 and Mn/TiO2 also display salient activities, which outperform by 1–6 orders of magnitude those of precious Ir/TiO2 below 400 K and Ru/TiO2 and Os/TiO2 in the whole temperature range considered. Although Nb, V and Cr-doped TiO2(110) are not as good as Ir/TiO2 and Ru/TiO2 catalysts, they display higher activity than Os/TiO2(110). Moreover, Mo and W atoms on TiO2(110) are less active than TiO2(110) at all temperatures in Fig. 4a. These results are clearly distinct from supported metal catalysts, where precious metals often showcase excellent CO oxidation activity [24,61]. Compared to the CA model, the reaction rate predicted by the SA model is generally lower, as shown in Fig. 4b. The activity ordering of M/TiO2 surfaces also varies drastically in the two models. According to the SA model, pure TiO2 and TiO2 doped with early transition metals such as Ta, Nb, V, Ti and Mo are inactive for CO oxidation, in contrast with the excellent activity of Ta/TiO2 and Nb/TiO2 predicted by the CA model. In brief, the absolute activities and the activity trends are different in the two models. This highlights the importance of input data for microkinetic modeling in SAC-at-oxide catalysts, where lattice oxygen may have strong repulsive or attractive interactions with the adsorbed species during catalytic cycles. Figs. 5 and S14 show the ratio of the rates for various CO oxidation routes and the total reaction rate as a function of temperature on M/TiO2(110). At all temperatures, CO oxidation proceeds through associative routes III and VI on TiO2(110). Although ΔE+ of the elementary reactions from the former are higher than the latter, the high O2* coverage observed in Fig. S15 favors the formation of (CO + O2)* and, hence, route III. The degree of rate control (DRC, see the Methods section) analysis in Fig. 6 shows that the CO2 formation rate on TiO2(110) is mainly determined by (CO + O2)* → CO2 + O*, which can be rationalized on the basis of its higher ΔE+ compared with the other elementary steps in route III (Table S7). Moreover, O2*(II) formation is also important in determining the overall rate, in contrast with O2* formation, which inhibits it. This is because both decreasing ΔE+ of the former step and increasing ΔE+ of the latter increase the coverage of O2*(II), favoring the formation of (CO + O2)*(II) and accelerating CO oxidation through (CO + O2)*(II) → CO3* (route VI). In the presence of M, the reaction mechanism has significant variations. If M is an early transition metal such as Ta, Nb, V, Cr, Mo and W, the dissociative routes dominate (Figs. 5 and S14). Specifically, routes I and II contribute almost equally on TiO2 doped with Ta, Nb, V and W. However, only routes II and I are found on Cr/TiO2 and Mo/TiO2, respectively, where only O2*(II) and O2* dissociation is available. The preference for dissociative routes of TiO2 doped with early transition metal atoms mainly stems from a combination of facile O2 dissociation and weak CO adsorption, which inhibits the formation of CO3* species (θ < 10−15) or CO2 via (CO + O2)*. In fact, (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + # determines to a great extent the overall rate on TiO2 doped with early transition metals (Figs. 6 and S16), in view of its higher ΔE+ compared to other elementary reactions in the dissociative routes (Table S7). This also explains the equivalent contribution from dissociative routes I and II on M/TiO2 (M = Ta, Nb, V, W). Specifically, as shown in Fig. 3a, routes I and II differ only in the initial two steps, namely the adsorption of O2* and O2*(II) and their dissociation into (2O)*. Afterwards, they undergo the same elementary steps. Since (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + # controls the rate of both routes, their contributions are equivalent. As M moves toward the right of the periodic table, associative routes VII or IV contribute almost as much as the dissociative routes (M = Mn, Ir, Ru) and even dominate the total rate (M = Rh and Os) on M/TiO2 except for M = Pt, as dissociative route II is more favorable. This is noticeably different from late transition metal nanoparticles, where the dissociative mechanism prevails [62]. This is probably because the O2*(III) precursor (Fig. S6f) is abundant on rutile supports [63], which favors the formation of CO3*, a key intermediate in the associative routes. Compared with TiO2 doped with early transition metals, the O2 dissociation activity decreases (M = Mn) or CO binding becomes stronger (M = Ru, Rh, Os, Ir) on TiO2 with late transition metal atoms, leading to large contributions from the associative routes. The dominance of the dissociative route on Pt/TiO2 in Fig. 5 is justified by the easily surmountable activation energies of relevant elementary reactions. Indeed, the elementary reactions from dissociative route II have lower ΔE+ than those from associative routes III and IV on Pt/TiO2 (Table S7). As shown in Fig. 6, O2*(II) dissociation to (2O)* controls the overall rate at low temperatures on Mn/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2, while (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + # controls it at higher temperatures. This is presumably because the reaction is controlled by kinetics at low temperatures, as O2*(II) dissociation has higher ΔE+ than (CO + 2O)*# → CO2 + O* + # in dissociative route II on those two surfaces and, as temperature increases, thermochemistry gains importance. In addition, O2* adsorption determines the overall rate on Mn/TiO2, whereas O2*(II) adsorption suppresses it. This is expectable because increased O2* coverage favors the formation of (CO + O2)* and enhances the formation of CO3* species through (CO + O2)* → CO3* in associative route IV, which contributes nearly as much as dissociative route II on Mn/TiO2. O2 adsorption in the presence of CO* controls to a great extent the overall rate on Rh/TiO2 and Ir/TiO2, since facile O2 co-adsorption with CO* facilitates the formation of CO3* and favors associative route VII. In Fig. 4 the rates of CO2 formation reach 105 s−1/site on Rh/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 at high temperatures. In these cases, surface diffusion of adsorbates, which is not included in the present microkinetic modeling, might become rate-limiting instead of elementary reactions. Besides, we studied the diffusion of Rh and Pt atoms from the TiO2 lattice to the hollow sites of surface O atoms. This process is endothermic by 1.91–3.34 eV regardless of the nature of M (Rh or Pt) and the oxidation state of TiO2 (stoichiometric or reduced). These results indicate that the Rh/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts are highly stable. Taking Pt/TiO2 as an example, we investigated its stability compared to adsorbed Pt (denoted as Pta/TiO2), PtO and PtO2 on stoichiometric TiO2(110) (see Fig. S17). The relative stability of various low-energy structures is assessed by the surface free energies ( γ ): [64] (5) γ = E total - N Pt ∙ E Pt - N Ti ∙ E Ti O 2 - 0.5 ∙ N O - 2 N Ti ∙ μ O 2 2 S where E total , E Pt , E Ti O 2 are the energy of the total system, the Pt atom and bulk TiO2; N Pt , N Ti , N O are the number of Pt, Ti and O atoms in the system, μ O 2 is the chemical potential of O2 and S is the surface area. As shown in Fig. S18, Pt/TiO2 is the most stable configuration under the studied conditions ( 320 - 500 K , P O 2 = 0.33 a t m ), which further confirms the reliability of our model. Moreover, (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + # controls the overall rate on Ru/TiO2 and Os/TiO2, likely in view of the high ΔE+ (0.61 and 0.86 eV). Previous works have shown that the rate-limiting step (RLS) often involves the removal of abundant surface species [65]. Specifically, the reaction (CO + O2)* = CO2 + O*, which displays large DRC values on TiO2(110), removes the most abundant O2* species (Figs. 6 and S15). Moreover, (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + # on M/TiO2 (M = Ta, Ru, Nb, V, Os, Cr, Mo, W) can remove the dominant (2O)* species (Fig. 6, S15-S16). In turn, O2 + CO* = (CO + O2)*(III) on Ir/TiO2 helps remove the abundant (CO + O2)* (Figs. 6 and S15). The switch of RLS as a function of temperature coincides with that of dominant surface species. At low temperatures, the RLS is O2*(II) dissociation on Pt/TiO2 and Mn/TiO2, which facilitates the removal of abundant O2*(II). With increasing temperature, (2O)* becomes the most abundant species, which is accompanied by the shift of the RLS to (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + #, and a similar phenomenon is observed on Rh/TiO2. Fig. S19 plots the CO oxidation rate ( Lnr , in s−1site−1) on various M/TiO2(110) at 400 K as a function of the pressures of CO ( Ln P CO ) and O2 ( LnP O 2 ). The reaction orders of CO ( α ) and O2 ( β ) are listed in Table S9. We observe in Table S9 that if M is an early transition metal, such as Ti–Cr, Nb, Mo, Ta and W, α = 1 and β = 0 . When M is a late transition metal, α and β change from one metal to the next. Negative values of α are observed on Rh/TiO2 and Ir/TiO2, and negative values of β on Ru/TiO2 and Os/TiO2. To the best of our knowledge, no experimentally apparent activation barriers are available for CO oxidation on single metal/rutile TiO2 catalysts, but we did find those of single metals (Ru, Rh, Ir and Pt) supported on MgO [66]. The simulated apparent activation barriers in Table S10 are generally lower than their counterparts on MgO, highlighting the great promise of our SACs/TiO2. Moreover, our apparent activation barriers of Rh/TiO2 are visibly larger than the experimental ones of Rh clusters/TiO2-P25 (Table S10) [67]. As this is the only major difference observed among the systems compared, we hypothesize that additional active sites might be present in experiments in this specific case (Rh/TiO2-P25 with ∼80 % anatase) compared to those in our Rh/TiO2. Lastly, the barriers are comparable for Pt/TiO2 and experimental Pt nanoparticles/TiO2-rutile (0.52 vs 0.67 eV) [60]. Compared to the CA model, the SA model predicts markedly different routes on various surfaces (see Figs. 5 and S14). Indeed, CO oxidation proceeds exclusively through route VII on TiO2 with Rh, Ir, Ru and Os atoms, and routes II and I on Cr/TiO2 and W/TiO2, respectively. However, the preferred route on Mn/TiO2 is temperature dependent. Route IV dominates the total rate at low temperatures, whereas route II becomes more favorable as the temperature increases to 500 K. In addition, the two models predict different RLSs, see Figs. 6 and S16. In the following, we will abridge the model by means of a descriptor-based analysis. The CO2 formation rates on M/TiO2(110) surfaces are often determined by (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + #, particularly at high temperature, as shown in Figs. 6 and S16. Section S16 proves that the reaction energy (ΔH) of this elementary step can be written as: (6) Δ H = E O ∗ - E C O + 2 O ∗ # + E C O 2 = R - Δ E A d s CO # - Δ E A d s O M where E O* and E (CO+2O)*# are the total energies of O* and (CO + 2O)*# (Fig. 3), and E CO2 is the total energy of CO2(g). R = E C O 2 - E O - E CO is a gas-phase reaction. In turn, ΔE Ads(CO#) is the adsorption energy of CO at the Ti site next to M on (2O)*-covered M/TiO2-x, and ΔE Ads(OM) is the adsorption energy of O at the M site of stoichiometric M/TiO2. Importantly, ΔE Ads(CO#) does not strongly depend on M, with variations of 0.14 eV at most on the surfaces under study, see Fig. S20. Therefore, differences in ΔH in Eq. (6) from one material to the next are mainly determined by ΔE Ads(OM). Since a reasonable BEP relation exists between ΔE+ and ΔH for that step (Fig. S13), we posit that ΔE Ads(OM) can be used as a descriptor of the CO oxidation activity. Indeed, Fig. 7 shows the CO oxidation activity as a function of ΔE Ads(OM) on M/TiO2(110) surfaces at 400 K. A volcano-shaped curve is observed with a maximum at ΔE Ads(OM) = −3.26 eV. The weak OM adsorption of TiO2(110) (ΔE Ads = −1.35 eV) inhibits O2*(II) dissociation and CO oxidation proceeds exclusively through associative routes. Conversely, strong OM adsorption on M/TiO2 (M = W, Mo, Os, Nb, ΔE Ads = −6.52 to −4.42 eV) facilitates O2 dissociation. CO oxidation on these surfaces proceeds via dissociative routes, but strong OM adsorption limits CO2 production. Because they have intermediate OM adsorption strength (ΔE Ads = −4.33 to −2.87 eV), such that both dissociative and associative routes contribute to CO oxidation, precious Pt, Rh, Ir, Ru and non-precious Mn and Ta atoms on TiO2(110) display enhanced activity for CO oxidation. For numerous elements there are PAWs with additional electrons in VASP. Table S11 compares the effect of the PAWs used in this work and others with additional electrons (denoted as extra) for Ti, Mo, Rh, Ta. For *CO the effect is small and positive: a v g Δ E Ads C O - Δ E Ads extra C O = 0.06 e V . For O2 and O the effect is larger but the differences are again nearly constant and positive: a v g Δ E Ads O 2 - Δ E Ads extra O 2 = 0.23 e V and a v g Δ E Ads O - Δ E Ads extra O = 0.25 e V . Hence, PAW-extras induce adsorbate-specific systematic strengthening of adsorption energies. We note that Mo,Ti, Os, V and Cr/TiO2 are far from the summit in Fig. 7, while Rh/TiO2 and Ta/TiO2 are close to the top. According to Fig. 7, if Mo, Os, V, Cr, Ta and Rh bind O more strongly, their activities should decrease slightly. Ti is on the opposite side of the volcano, so its activity should increase slightly. However, the three activity regions (strong, moderate and weak coupling) and trends in Fig. 7 should remain unchanged given the large energy span of the x-axis (∼5 eV) and the logarithmic scale in the y-axis. Finally, Table S12 shows the minor effect of the PAWs on the magnetic moments, with variations < 0.05 μB on the surfaces studied. The fact that a single parameter, namely ΔE Ads(OM), suffices as a descriptor for M/TiO2 catalysts is markedly different from supported metal catalysts, where the adsorption energies of O and CO are typically necessary to describe CO oxidation [24,68], as O and CO binding energies are generally linearly independent on metals. However, multiple sites exist on M/TiO2 catalysts, such as the bridge O vacancy, Ti sites next to M, and M, and all of them are involved in CO oxidation. We note that although oxygen adsorption at the bridge O vacancy (O*) depends on M, it is not involved in the RLS (i.e., (CO + 2O)*# = CO2 + O* + #). The adsorption of CO at the Ti site next to M (CO#) on (2O)*-covered surfaces does not depend on M. Hence, only O adsorption at the M site (OM) affects strongly the CO oxidation activity of M/TiO2 catalysts. Evidently, a single descriptor conveniently simplifies the analysis and can potentially save computational costs during materials screening. Our descriptor may be applied to other single-metal-decorated catalysts for CO oxidation or in other important reactions of academic and industrial interest involving CO and oxygenated species, such as electrochemical CO oxidation, which is key in direct alcohol fuel cells, WGS and rWGS [28,69–75]. In summary, a strong interaction exists between bridge O and adsorbed species at M sites on M/TiO2 catalysts. Neglecting such interaction in a separate adsorption model leads to substantial differences in activation energies, reaction routes, rate-limiting steps and catalytic activity predictions for CO oxidation, highlighting the often overlooked importance of adsorbate interactions in catalyst screening. 4 Conclusions Seeking suitable SACs for CO oxidation, we used DFT calculations and microkinetic modeling to elucidate the interaction between single 3d–5d metal atoms M and rutile TiO2(110). To abridge the model, we identified the adsorption energy of O at M sites as a simple and predictive descriptor for the CO oxidation activity of M/TiO2 catalysts, which is different from supported metal catalysts, as those require two adsorption-energy descriptors. In line with the Sabatier principle, our descriptor classifies M/TiO2 catalysts into three categories: (i) weak O adsorption (e.g., TiO2), which inhibits O2*(II) dissociation, so that CO oxidation proceeds exclusively through associative routes; (ii) strong O adsorption on M/TiO2 (M = W, Mo, Os, Nb, V, Cr), which hurdles its recombination, so that CO oxidation mainly proceeds via dissociative routes; (iii) intermediate O adsorption on precious Pt, Rh, Ir, Ru and non-precious Mn and Ta atoms embedded in TiO2, which accelerates CO oxidation by enabling both dissociative and associative routes. This work features the importance of adsorbate interactions to accurately describe CO oxidation kinetics on M/TiO2 catalysts, where strong substrate-mediated interactions between adsorbed species exist. The insights provided here may be used to guide experiments and be applied to different SAC architectures for CO oxidation and akin reactions of technological interest. coredata.dc:description: Single-atom catalysts (SACs) display prominent performance and high metal utilization for numerous catalytic processes. Harnessing the interaction between single atoms and supports is crucial to improve the performance of SACs. By means of density functional theory calculations and microkinetic modeling including adsorbate interactions, we expose the promising synergy between 3d–5d single metal atoms (M) and TiO2(110) for CO oxidation. Upon a rigorous analysis, we identify the adsorption energy of O at M sites as a simple and robust descriptor to abridge the design of catalysts for CO oxidation on M/TiO2 catalysts, so that enhanced activities are predicted at mild O adsorption energies. Single Pt and Rh atoms provide the largest enhancement around 400 K, with CO2 formation rates 7–8 orders of magnitude higher than on TiO2(110). Non-precious Ta/TiO2 and Mn/TiO2 also exhibit salient activities. This work highlights the often disregarded yet central role of adsorbate interactions in CO oxidation.
